transcripts.text: Our guest is Miss Ayn Rand, authoress of Atlas Shrugged and The Fountainhead and We the Living.  She advocates a new morality, an ethics of, as she puts it, rational self-interest that stands, it appears, in complete opposition to the political and social and religious attitudes of our day.  Her unique philosophy is known as objectivism.
I would like to ask Miss Rand, what can the United States do to bring full equality for the American
plain decent treatment without completely changing our free enterprise system or radically upsetting

our entire economic system.  There is no reason why anybody should have equal housing with everybody else.  You're not talking about an economic issue.  There certainly is inequality of housing, inequality of income among men of all races, certainly among white men.  Therefore, there is no reason why minorities should be guaranteed housing.  The only thing you can properly discuss is racial prejudice.  The only issue here is to treat every individual man as a human being and judge him according to his own actions, his own character, his own performance.  Therefore, all that you can discuss properly is to guarantee individual political rights.  And that the government can do by not permitting any legislation which discriminates legally.  But now if you speak about private prejudice, racial prejudice that cannot be achieved or eliminated by law.  In order to eliminate private discrimination, you should advocate individual rights and the philosophy that goes with it.  I will refer you to my article entitled Racism in my book The Virtue of Selfishness, in which I discuss the fact that racism is just the lowest, most primitive form of collectivism.  And in any period of history when collectivism is on the rise, men are forced to cling to one another into groups, to seek groups.  because a collectivist society or a mixed economy like we have today is a society of pressure group warfare.  And the easiest collective to join, particularly of men of not great intelligence, is race.  Therefore, racism, the prejudice of racial groups against one another, is a byproduct of collectivism.  Men are taught that the individual has no rights, has no meaning, no significance outside of his group.  Only groups count.  That is the essence of collectivism.  And consequently, racism is on the rise.  The only way to abolish racism, private racism, is by advocating individualism and its corollary, a free society.  In a free society, the white man's own rational self-interest would abolish racism, and those who are irrational, those who insist on running their business or their lives by racial prejudices, would be their own victims.  They should be boycotted by rational men and they should be ostracized.  That is, those who are not racist should refuse to deal with those who are guilty of racial prejudice.  But you cannot forbid prejudice by law.  A racist has a right not to associate with other people if he doesn't want to.  Just as a communist, has a right to preach his ideas, to have his freedom of speech, even though his ideas are evil.  In a free society, neither the communist nor the racist would be of much danger to anyone, and would gradually be eliminated by people's enlightenment and by people's rational self-interest.
Thank you very much, Phil Kolsa.

Ms.  Rand, I want to thank you very much, and in the last two minutes, I really say this sincerely, I have learned more in the last two minutes than five years of any intensive study on my part, and I want to thank you again.
